title: 104_hr3434
content:
The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" limits representation or advising of certain foreign entities. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" imposes restrictions on former officers or employees representing foreign entities within 10 or 5 years after their service ends. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" restricts former officers or employees from representing foreign entities within 5 years after their service ends, unless certain conditions are met. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" prohibits former US officers or employees from representing foreign entities within 5 years of their service ending, unless specific conditions are met. This includes individuals who provide advice or services related to matters where the US is involved. Compensation for such services is defined broadly to include payments, gifts, benefits, rewards, favors, or gratuities. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" defines key terms related to compensation, foreign governments, foreign political parties, and the United States. It broadens the scope of what constitutes compensation for services rendered. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" expands the definition of the term 'State' to include the District of Columbia and any U.S. commonwealth, territory, or possession. The effective date of this amendment is January 1, 1997, with exceptions for individuals whose service ended before this date. SEC. 3. CROSS-OVER LOBBYING. The text discusses additional restrictions on lobbying for former executive and legislative branch officials, imposing penalties for attempting to influence members of Congress within one year of leaving government service. Any former Member of Congress or employee of the House of Representatives or Senate with a salary over 120% of GS-15 pay, who tries to influence the executive branch within a year of leaving, will be punished under section 216. SEC. 4. FELONS.

Former Members of Congress, certain high-salary former employees of Congress, and certain executive branch employees convicted of a felony are prohibited from making compensated communications to government employees.

SEC. 5. EXEMPTION BASED ON REGISTRATION UNDER LOBBYING ACT.

Amendment to the Foreign Agents Registration Act exempts individuals engaged in lobbying activities who have registered from certain requirements.

SEC. 6. CIVIL PENALTIES. Section 3(h) of the Foreign Agents Registration Act is amended to require individuals engaged in lobbying activities to register. Civil penalties for violations of the Act are increased to a maximum of $50,000 per violation.
